name: transport, freight, lorry 28 metric ton, fatty acid methyl ester 100% | transport, freight, lorry 28 metric ton, fatty acid methyl ester 100% | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/8474/documentation

Inventory refers to the entire transport life cycle. For road infrastructure, expenditures and environmental interventions due to construction of roads have been allocated based on the Gross tonne kilometre performance. Expenditures due to operation of the road infrastructure, as well as land use have been allocated based on the yearly vehicle kilometre performance. For the attribution of vehicle share to the transport performance a vehicle life time performance of 3.14E06 tkm/vehicle have been assumed. An average load of 5.82 t/vehicle is assumed. The data of the energy use and combustion emissions represents average data for the  operation of heavy duty vehicles (20-28t) in Switzerland, with an average load of  50%. The transport datasets 'operation of a vehicle' are related to life cycles of other products and using the reference unit of [km].

The dataset starts with the consumption of rape methyl ester.

operation, lorry 28t, rape methyl ester 100%; lorry 28t; maintenance, lorry 28t; road;  for the data of the energy use and combustion emissions: rape methyl ester, at regional storage supplies is included. Direct airborne emissions of gaseous substances, particulate matters and heavy metals are accounted for. Heavy metal emissions to water and to soil are included. Tyre abrasion is included.
category: H:Transportation and storage/49:Land transport and transport via pipelines/492:Other land transport/4923:Freight transport by road

processDocumentation.geographyDescription: The data for vehicle operation and road infrastructure reflect Swiss conditions. Data for vehicle manufacturing and maintenance represents generic European data. Data for the vehicle disposal reflect Swiss situation. The data of the energy use and combustion emissions refer to average transport conditions in Switzerland.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Vehicle operation: Euro3. Road construction comprises bitumen and concrete roads. For the manufacturing of vehicles, the data reflects current modern technologies. operation, lorry 28t, rape methyl ester 100%. operation, lorry 28t, rape methyl ester 100%. These data include precombustion emissions, exhaust emissions or tail pipe emissions as well as non-exhaust emissions due to vehicle motion, e.g. tyre abrasion.

flow.name: transport, freight, lorry 28 metric ton, fatty acid methyl ester 100%
flow.category: H:Transportation and storage/49:Land transport and transport via pipelines/492:Other land transport/4923:Freight transport by road

exchanges.description: Calculated value. For consistency, the kilometric performance, the infrastructure data, and the demand factors for the transport components have been adopted from Spielmann et al. (2004), i.e. are derived from ecoinvent database. It is assumed, that these factors do not depend on the type of fuel. This means that in case of 28-t lorry, an average load of 5.82 t per vehicle was assumed.

flow.name: road maintenance
flow.category: F:Construction/42:Civil engineering/421:Construction of roads and railways/4210:Construction of roads and railways

exchanges.description:
Literature value. The emission factors were derived on the basis of a literature research (CPCB 2003; EPA 2002; Hendriksen et al. 2003; Keller et al. 1998; Keller et al. 2005; Lance and Anderson 2003; Lehmann 2002; Munack et al. 2003; Ohltröm et al. 2001; Scharmer et al. 2001; UFOP 2004; VCA 2004). Energy use and combustion emissions

Further References:

Hendriksen P., Vermeulen R.J., Rijkeboer R.C., Bremmers D., Smokers R.T.M. and Winkel R.G. (2003) Evaluation of the envrionmental impact of modern passenger cars on petrol, diesel, automotive LPG, CNG. TNO Report No. 03.OR.VM.055.1/PHE, Netherlands Organisation for Applied Scientific Research, Delft.

Keller et al. (1998) Ökprofile von Treibstoffen. BUWAL Umwelt-Materialien Nr-104, Bern.

Keller M., de Haan P., Knörr W., Hausberger S. and Steven H. (2004) Handobook Emission Factor for Road Transport, Version 2.1, Umweltbundesamt Berlin, Swiss Agency for the Envrionment, Forest and Landscape, Umweltbundesamt Wien, INFRAS, Bern.

Lance D. & Andersson J. (2003) DfT Biofuels Evaluation - Final Report of Teste Programme to Evaluate Emissions Performance of Vegetable Oil Fuel on Two Light Duty Diesel Vehicles. Ricardo Consulting Engineers, West Sussex.

Lehmann U. (2002) Bio-Ethanol Projekt, Untersuchungsbericht Nr. 202672, EMPA, Eidgenössische Materialprüfungs- und Forschungsanstalt, Dübendorf.

Munack A., Stein H., Bünger J., Schröder O. and Krahl J. (2003) Systematiche Untersuchungen der Emissionen aus der motorischen Verbrennung von RME, MK1 und DK. FAL Bundesfroschungsanstalt für landwirtschaft, Brauschweig.

Ohlström M., Mäkinen T. Laurikko J. and Pipatti R. (2001) New concepts for biofuels in transportation, VTT research notes.

Literature value. Non-exhaust emissions are mainly produced from tyre abrasion, break wear and road abrasion. Spielmann et al. (2004) give an overview of the kind and amounts of the respective emissions. Since these emission factors do not depend on the type of consumed fuel, the values given in Spielmann et al. (2004) were adopted for the present study and applied for each transport system. Energy use and combustion emissions

Literature value. Non-exhaust emissions are mainly produced from tyre abrasion, break wear and road abrasion. Spielmann et al. (2004) give an overview of the kind and amounts of the respective emissions. Since these emission factors do not depend on the type of consumed fuel, the values given in Spielmann et al. (2004) were adopted for the present study and applied for each transport system. Energy use and combustion emissions

Calculated value. For consistency, the kilometric performance, the infrastructure data, and the demand factors for the transport components have been adopted from Spielmann et al. (2004), i.e. are derived from ecoinvent database. It is assumed, that these factors do not depend on the type of fuel. This means that in case of 28-t lorry, an average load of 5.82 t per vehicle was assumed.

exchanges.description: Literature value. Non-exhaust emissions are mainly produced from tyre abrasion, break wear and road abrasion. Spielmann et al. (2004) give an overview of the kind and amounts of the respective emissions. Since these emission factors do not depend on the type of consumed fuel, the values given in Spielmann et al. (2004) were adopted for the present study and applied for each transport system. Energy use and combustion emissions

Calculated value. The fuel consumption was derived from carbon balance calculation, considering the carbon content of measured tail pipe emissions of CO2, CO and CH4. Following the ecoinvent procedure, the carbon contents of NMVOC-emissions are neglected. Note that the calculated fuel consumption was not always in good correspondence with the according literature values. One possible reason for the differences is that the measurements were based on a fuel with slightly different carbon content than the fuel specified within the study; another possible reason is the neglection of the carbon content of NMVOC in the carbon balance. Energy use and combustion emissions

Literature value. Non-exhaust emissions are mainly produced from tyre abrasion, break wear and road abrasion. Spielmann et al. (2004) give an overview of the kind and amounts of the respective emissions. Since these emission factors do not depend on the type of consumed fuel, the values given in Spielmann et al. (2004) were adopted for the present study and applied for each transport system. Energy use and combustion emissions

Literature value. The emission factors were derived on the basis of a literature research (CPCB 2003; EPA 2002; Hendriksen et al. 2003; Keller et al. 1998; Keller et al. 2005; Lance and Anderson 2003; Lehmann 2002; Munack et al. 2003; Ohltröm et al. 2001; Scharmer et al. 2001; UFOP 2004; VCA 2004). Calculated value. For consistency, the kilometric performance, the infrastructure data, and the demand factors for the transport components have been adopted from Spielmann et al. (2004), i.e. are derived from ecoinvent database. It is assumed, that these factors do not depend on the type of fuel. This means that in case of 28-t lorry, an average load of 5.82 t per vehicle was assumed.
